Problem:
Consider a dynamical system described by the partial differential equation \\( u_t = Lu \\), where L is a linear differential operator. We examine the effects of a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(t)) \\) applied to the spatial component of \\( u \\) and how it translates through time.

If the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(u_0) \\) is applied to an initial function \\( u_0 \\) and then the system evolves according to \\( u_t = Lu \\) without additional manipulation, will the Fourier transform of \\( u(t) \\) at t = T be equivalent to the result of directly evolving \\( \\mathcal{F}(u_0) \\) under the transformed operator \\( \\mathcal{F}(L) \\mathcal{F}^{-1} \\)?
Explanation: The Fourier transform of the evolution equation \\( u_t = Lu \\) leads to the transformed equation under \\( \\mathcal{F}(L) \\). This means that evolving \\( \\mathcal{F}(u_0) \\) under \\( \\mathcal{F}(L) \\mathcal{F}^{-1} \\) using the Fourier transformed rules successfully predicts \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(t)) \\) at time T, since the Fourier transform linearly translates the effects of L on u.
